description: No longer a New York City cop, Max Payne moves to São Paulo to protect a wealthy family in an effort to finally escape his troubled past. This was a tough call to make. I wanted to like Max Payne 3, but it just really did not want to be liked. The good news is, at the core, the gameplay is actually pretty good... when you get to play it, but more on that in a bit. The combat is true to the John Woo style of the series. The game is also considerably more difficult than Max Payne 2, but not as much as Max Payne 1, which is a happy medium. It's a bit heavily cover-based, but you do have the shootdodge at your disposal to mix things up.   Unfortunately, you will spend the majority of your gaming hours locked in sequence after sequence of unskippable AND unquittable cutscenes which smugly display the text 'still loading' when you try to skip them, despite the fact that it has clearly been 5 minutes or more. If you try to press escape, the cutscene will just pause. Once the gameplay actually begins and you start to have fun, the instant the last guy is killed you are forced to watch a 30 second cutscene of Max opening a door or vaulting a ledge, or something else you could have easily done yourself. It often doesn't even allow you time to search the room for guns, painkillers, or collectibles. When you do get the opportunity to scavenge the room after a battle, you cannot backtrack to the previous room (which is always inexplicably locked behind you) and you are CONSTANTLY nagged every five seconds to proceed forward, either by one of Max's allies or Max himself. He'll say to himself, 'I had no time to admire the scenery, I had to move forward,' as if he's in a rush to finish his own story. I suppose he needs to make time for more compelling details in his storytelling such as 'there was a security door across the hall' or some contextual remark on every bottle of pills that he finds.   The general flow of the game, as you may have guessed, between all the cutscenes is just shooting gallery after shooting gallery. In many a cutscene you have the dubious privilege of watching Max bumble his way into a room, alerting the entire mob, and spoiling what would have been a perfectly good sneak attack. And after the game spends most of its time yanking you forward against your will, in other chapters you will be forced to slowly walk or stagger drunk or wounded through the level for ten minutes, unable to actually do anything useful. It absolutely refuses to let you play at your own pace.  But that's just the story mode -- if you want to just shoot stuff in combat scenarios without all the talky talk then surely Arcade mode is where it's at... right? Ehhh, no. The only difference Arcade mode has is that it removes the *skippable* cutscenes from the game, which there weren't that many of to begin with. Wonderful. And it gives you a score at the end of the chapter, with none of the instant gratification the game so callously denies you.

***LONG REVIEW WARNING***  I’m not sure how many times I actually asked myself “Why?” as I played Max Payne 3. “Why is he doing this?” “Why did they make this design decision?” “Why am I supposed to care?” It would go from the typical reflexive inquiries, to the borderline obsessive ones. I would continue after every stumble, extending a hand to the game, picking it up and giving it another chance to attempt walking. Eventually, I just decided to drag it until we reached the end of the road and left it there.  There is not much that makes Max Payne 3 a bad game, but rather, there is plenty that makes it a bad sequel. I’ve seen and participated in various discussions on the subject, seeing many dodgy arguments as to why people liked or hated the game. There’s a clear discontent among a certain number of people, as though something was missing in the title. Possibly the most common claim being “it’s not noir”.  And that is a claim that is as hard to support as it is to debunk. Men smarter and more qualified than either you or I have spent decades tackling this subject alone. Whether noir is an aesthetic or genre, or whether it even exists to begin with. Even among people who agree that noir exists, the criteria varies, and any “List of film noir titles” on Wikipedia or in any book wouldn’t be accurate. However, the golden age of noir died when the genre became self-aware, so now it would be more accurate to call anything written in a noir “style” neo-noir.  Claiming that either the setting or the daylight denies Max Payne 3’s right to carry the banner is dodgy at best. Many noteworthy noir titles, like White Heat, were set during the day without it being detrimental to the atmosphere. There are many other reasons to say the game lost its noir charm, but such a discussion would last for an eternity with no side being able to win. Something that can be agreed upon, though, is that if Max Payne 3 is indeed neo-noir, it is of a different ilk compared to the previous two games. Quite reasonable if you consider that movies like Sin City and American Beauty both count as neo-noir while being vastly different.  The first two games were a fusion of extreme noir melodrama and John Woo-style gunplay. It reached absurd levels story-wise, often mocking itself, but also placed a character who had rational reactions to the grimdark world around him. It’s why when you completely immerse yourself in the game, you never question Max’s actions. It never tears you away from the screen. But when you walk away and think about it, you realize just how unreasonable and silly the entire plot is.  The third game makes the mistake of toning down the setting into a more realistic one. Nothing is over the top, and there’s more emphasis on realism (as far as a third person shooter can allow). All of a sudden, we are asking questions we otherwise wouldn’t have. Our immersion breaks with every conflict between what the cutscenes imply and what the gameplay implies. Not only that, but all of a sudden, Max Payne stops being about Max and focuses on the events around him. This distinction is clear when you take into account that neither the first, nor the second game offers any sort of epilogue. It starts and ends with Max. On the other hand, Max Payne 3 offers a proper “this is what happened after Max put the gun down” scene.  This difference in atmosphere doesn’t stem only from the narrative, but also from the gameplay. Whether it was due to technical limitations, or just a savvy decision, Remedy used a minimal amount of in-game cutscenes. If Max sees an object he wants to comment on, the player needs to actually approach it by moving Max. Rockstar’s approach was to force the player’s movement, whether by cutscene or just slowing Max down due to injuries or the environment. The latter isn’t even much of an issue and is a better alternative to cutscenes, but coupled with them, it sets a much slower pace. Even trivial design decisions, like taking away the player’s control when watching TV, damages the experience.  The combat also follows this change of pace. Max Payne 3’s combat does revolve around cover, which is true to the predecessors save for the addition of a “stick to the wall” button. But it quickly becomes binary. You either have bullet-time, or you don’t. You are either at full health, or nearly dead. With infinite bullet-time jumps and only putting a cap on regular slow-mo movement, the pace changes drastically. Before, Max could jump into the action guns blazing. Now? Every single enemy is a threat, putting more emphasis on the previously mentioned increase in realism.  And then, of course, there is the actual character of Max Payne, probably the biggest problem with the latest game. Someone once told me that Max is very good at lying to himself. That’s quite an accurate statement. After all, at the end of the first game, he thought blood revenge would give him peace of mind, but as the second game showed us, it didn’t quite work out that way. However, at the end of Max Payne 2, regardless of which ending you got, Max was at peace with himself. It wasn’t something questionable like “this person is dead, everything is fine now”, but merely the culmination of all events just pushing him to a realization.  And obviously, he lied to himself again, according to Max Payne 3. This leaves a branching path, where one says that Rockstar wasn’t true to the character, while the other says they were. With the latter, one has to wonder why we should even care for the character now. There is a difference between falling on tough times and picking yourself up, and actually having two opportunities to take your life back and get at least a bittersweet ending. Payne stops being a powerful determinator and turns into this Guy With the Gun bum. A person one would find hard to care for. It would be easier for those who entered the series with this newest installment, as the predecessors become one big blur called “the dark past”, but as someone who played through both events, I find it quite difficult to ignore this kind of character development.  This is not the only issue when speaking of Max, though. His mannerisms are also drastically different. Despite the tone and rating of all games, Max rarely, if ever, swore in the first two games. I was halfway through the second game recently and I’m not quite sure if I even heard a “damn” from him. He had a sort of cold composure, dealing with his issues within himself, rather than swearing, raging and generally being openly upset about the situation. The trademark noir metaphors are also close to nonexistent now. Most of Max’s statements have become plain observations, rather than actually processing the information as he did before. No melodramatic thoughts on life beyond the occasional pearl in an ocean of dry writing.   As Payne himself says in the second game: “If you had done something differently, it wouldn’t be you, it would be someone else looking back, asking a different set of questions.” And that is what the core issue with Max Payne 3 is, in the end. It’s not about Max Payne. It’s about someone else with the same problems, dealing with them in their own way. There are many other issues we haven’t mentioned, like the highly out of place shock about the organ black market, or the redundant “Do you kill him or let him live?” prompt at the end of the game. Max Payne 3 suffers from Fallout 3 syndrome. Just how Fallout 3 was a good game, but awful Fallout, so is Max Payne 3 a good game on its own, but an abysmal addition to the series.  One only has to wonder where Remedy would have taken Max Payne 3 had they been the developers. “Max Payne’s journey through the night will continue,” say the credits of the second game. Sadly, most of the levels of Max Payne 3 were in broad daylight.

Max Payne 3 is a beautiful game, with visuals that can barely be rivaled by other games currently on the market. Contrary to Rockstar’s history, Max Payne 3 is a wonderful PC port, putting their last port, GTA IV, to shame. Max Payne 3 runs on all sorts of systems and doesn’t require the most up to date equipment to run. Sadly, Max Payne 3’s multiplayer experience is a bit flawed, as it is plagued with Russians (Like Dota 2) and hackers (most of which are Russians).   Hopefully with more patches, the amount of Reds ruining multiplayer will decrease. In the end, Max Payne 3 is an experience that all gamers should enjoy, one of the best games of 2012.

Rewriting my review since the old one did not do it justice. Max Payne 3, the sequel to the fantastic 2003 Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne, is an entertaining, thrilling, amazing experience from start to finish.    STORY:   Set in São Paulo, the protagonist, Max Payne, is a retired ol' NYCPD cop. Max’s diet consists of liquor and painkillers to make him forget the sorrows of what had happened to him and his deceased family. Desperate to get out of his pitiful condition, he takes a job as a bodyguard for a rich Brazilian businessman named Fabricas Branco. But it turns out that it isn't an easy job after all, when Fabiana, Fabricas' wife, is kidnaped. The plot is full of conspiracies and sick twists and huge amazing set pieces and in the end... it pays off; it is one of the best stories told in a video game.    GAMEPLAY:   Simple yet incredibly fun, with a huge array of weapons to choose from, you shoot, jump and make amazing 'Matrix' style tricks that are not strange for Max Payne fans. The gunplay also received some polish as it is refined and perfected.    GRAPHICS:   The game is beautiful from art direction to meshes and polygons. Animations are one of the best around. Surprisingly, the game is very well optimized and it utilizes many PC-specific features such as DirectX11. (which is weird for a Rockstar game)    AUDIO:   Voice acting is top notch with James McCaffrey returning as Max Payne. The soundtrack is AWESOME, don’t believe me? Just check out 'Tears by Health' on YouTube, you'll love it!    MULTIPLAYER:   For the first time ever in a Max Payne game, a multiplayer mode is included. Many people were skeptical about it but it turned out that they were all wrong. This fun creative experience has all the single player abilities such as Bullet Time and Shootdodge in it which makes it stand out from the crowd. it is fast paced and (sometimes) chaotic and balanced.  Overall it was my personal 2012 GOTY and it still is.   10/10

Max Payne 3 is a fantastic game.   It's an action oriented third person shooter, basically. Where this game shines is in the details and the impressive challenge it can present to you. While the story is...alright, this game is amazing in how Max narrates the story and the events around him. There is a definite homage to film noir, and Max's chilling narrations are both incredibly well written and hauntingly appropriate.  Max moves in a very realistic way, turning his body and rolling and falling in a way that's very believable, despite some moments in the game where you sorta...jump the shark in terms of action. There's an IMMENSE focus on headshots and precision, and you will most certainly have a hard time beating this game if you are not a good shot. There are multiple difficulty settings, but even Normal can present a good challenge at times.  The use of bullet time is central to the game's mechanics, but Max Payne 3 uses it well, sometimes scripted in it's use, but also allowing you to use the limited function to engage large groups of enemies for Die Hard-esque cinematic style asskickery.  The game also looks fantastic, and the game runs smoothly. I haven't experienced any bugs or glitches in it. Rockstar did a great job making a PC version of this game. Aiming is responsive and won't hold you back or hinder you. It's just you, your gun, and your aim.  I definitely recommend if you enjoy shooters that take skill, are full of action, and basically just trying to get as many people as possible to stop your bullets with the bridge of their noses.

'First day off the sauce and somehow I'd still ended up in the gutter.'  'I needed to find a way upstairs. Surely no one would notice another hole in the wall.'  'I started to wonder if my luck had finally run out when I realized it had, a long time ago. It's why I was here.'  -Max Payne   Good old self-deprecating Max is more quotable than ever before in  Max Payne 3 , the latest installment by  Rockstar Studios  into one of my favorite series. The above are just a tiny sample of the nonstop narration he delivers to flavor the single-player campaign experience. In my opinion this alone would justify playing through the game, even if it didn't have solid mechanics, excellent visuals and fun features like Bullet Time.    My time played (almost 10 hours as of this writing) reflects campaign completion on the Hard setting, some dabbling in the arcade mode and a few rounds of the extensively fleshed out multiplayer modes. Even a brief foray into multiplayer reveals that there's plenty of progression to be had for those willing to pour hours into it. Like any brilliant solo campaign, this one is an absolute thrill ride but feels tragically brief once finished.   The story is not what I'd call ambitious but for the most part holds up well: Max is a classic and highly satisfying tale of tragedy with dark comedy mixed in. He's simply one of the most likeable antiheroes I've come across in gaming. The choice of setting provides an interesting, colorful departure from the grit and grime of the noir style that characterized the previous games (but don't worry, there's some of that here, too). Fans of the IP will recognize a few throwbacks to those predecessors.    Gameplay is functional and engaging. Level design is mostly good, but here and there feels uninspired/recycled, which makes me wonder about the quality of all those DLC map packs I didn't buy. Bullet time is tons of fun, rewarding twitch aim & fast reflexes. On Hard difficulty there were only a few encounters I had to replay, and the frustration was minor so I'd recommend that setting. Multiplayer--despite the variety of play modes, maps, weapons and avatar customizations--did not capture my interest, nor did I find the progression or social systems appealing. I'm sure it comes down to personal preference, so I recommend you at least try it out, but for me personally there are better options when it comes to online shooters. The arcade modes and time trials were also only of marginal interest to me so I won't discuss them here. The strength of Max Payne 3 for players like me lies in the campaign.   The game appears bug free and has only minor issues. During my hours played it only crashed once. It ran smoothly with settings maxed--granted, the game is two and a half years old at the time of this review, but the visuals hold up well enough to triple A standards unless you're talking about top of the line resolutions. I found it odd that weapons with a laser sight attachment were less accurate/useful than the standard ones due to the loss of crosshairs on screen in aim mode. Also a bother was how the triggered Bullet Time would force me into my 1-handed weapon; threw me off a bit if I was using 2-handed and suddenly encountered an event. On rare occasion activating Bullet Time will send you jumping over the edge of something like a building or dock, which is instant-death bad news, so be careful to avoid that very annoying problem. The last and worst offender I have to mention is Rockstar's Social Club which in my opinion is an unwelcome and failed DRM-like hoop to jump through. If when you first launch the game you can't sign into your account, go to their website and change your password then restart the game and it should log you in and let you register/activate the game just fine.   I had a great time with this one and honestly would recommend it to any gamer who enjoys the action shooter, which Rockstar does extremely well.  TIP: Use your Bullet Time wisely, as it will make fights much more manageable and sometimes save your bacon. Timing and position are important. TIP: Keep your gun reloaded to avoid having an emptied clip while downed. Downed w/no bullets = dead.

A third-person shooter featuring Max Payne and his trademark 'slow motion' action, set in a crime dominated Brazil (not very far from the truth, unfortunately).  Unlike other games in the series, Max Payne 3 attempts to address social issues instead of the main character’s personal issues, such as police violence, the gap between the rich and the poor and drug trafficking in Brazil.  Here, the rich try to live the American life style, while the poor are slaughtered. Payne witnesses a favela raid and a prison riot, in scenes reminiscent of some Brazilian movies like 'City of God', 'Carandiru' and 'Elite Squad'.  Even after facing a satanic cult, Max Payne is still surprised by the violence of the Brazilian police. In this game, the police are the real enemy, not the gangsters. The police are involved in the most heinous crimes, with the support of a corrupt politician.  The game features a São Paulo dominated by organized and disorganized crime. A Brazil that worships soccer, where poor people are killed by the police, while the rich are vying with each other through drug watered parties. Is this so far from reality?  There are two interesting characters: the American ex-cop who does volunteer work in Brazil, and the sex tourist. Both sides of the relationship between Brazilians and Americans. But in the end, Payne is the hero. Not unlike any american action movie, after all.  Good action for those who like action movies set in 'exotic' slums.  Positive points * Great action and graphics. * Multiplayer cooperative mode.  Negative points * Brazilian portuguese voice-acting kinda sucks. * Challenges are boring to complete.
My Personal Score: 3/5

7/10  The game was way too short. So seamless, continuous and yet, so short. What the game lacks in plot, it makes up for in action. We remember the Max Payne franchise for the terrific plots and character development of every character in the story. Well, the character development was there, but the plot, since it was just Max looking doing his job and later, trying to save the girl and then, looking for revenge, wore a bit thin. We're used to those unbelieable nightmare sequences where Max was battling his own demons. Here, the only demons he was fighting was alcoholism. Sure, he's a retired cop doing a private security job in a different country but I would have loved to see the plot having some sort of intimacy with Max himself.   But the action was very realistic. One could tell how bullet time and covering behind objects was seamlessly integrated. Max even uses his hands to disarm enemies in close combat and can't carry more more weapons than his outfits allow him to. The voiceover is great, as usual. James McCaffrey did a splendid job, although it could be a little dissonant listening to Max's voice when we're trying to listen to enemies coming through a room!   You should play this game, irrespective of whether you've played the previous two games.

Max Payne 3 can be summarized in one sentence: Shooting Brazilian gang members and paramilitary forces with the use of slow motion and John Woo's Hard Boiled in one hell of a game. I used to play the previous two Max Payne games back in my original Xbox and the third game is hard to describe. The genre of the game is a hybrid of crime thriller with a sheer blend of intense firefights, containing the cinematography of Tony Scott's 2004 film, Man on Fire. Strangely enough, Max Payne is more cynical about himself and his surroundings. If you know what happened in the first two games, then you should know why he acted in such attitude. The story in the game is rather...complex up to the point that it is confusing on what's happening and who's who. The narration mixes up to Max's current situation in Brazil and his past in New Jersey and Panama Canal. Unfortunately, the story progression tends to go back and forth of Max's past and present, ruining the mood on certain points of the story. Without a doubt, the gameplay is highly impressive with excellent body movement and human flexibility for Max to fire his weapon at any position. However, the game does feel a bit repetitive and can be difficult for some gamers to not play the entire game in one sitting. Overall, the game is recommended to those who like slow motion, action movies particularly John Woo's Heroic Bloodshed films, and gun play. However, the game may not be for some gamers who are more story centric (even though there were some surprising moments in the story). The story's good and may feel a bit 'uncomfortable' in certain parts of the story. It has my recommendation.

The hard-boiled detective is back, but is this the same Max that we've seen in before?  A new Max Payne game! Set in Brazil!? I have to admit that I was perplexed, perhaps even turned off at this idea when I initially heard about it. After all, Max Payne had established itself as a melodramatic noir crime story set in New York City, the complete opposite of its new sunny, colorful, Brazilian setting. Along with the new setting there were also new developers, while previous titles were handled by Finnish studio Remedy Games, Max Payne 3 was being developed by an internal Rockstar studio in Vancouver. This definitely raised a few eyebrows, mine especially. How did it all turn out?  Wonderfully.  Max has never felt better. Controls are snappy. The animations are some of the best I've ever seen in gaming. The story is a little lacking, but all we really needed is Max with guns, truckloads of bad guys, and bullet time.  The dark and brooding atmosphere of the first two games is replaced by an aesthetic that closely resembles a Tony Scott film, particularly the film Man on Fire. There are a lot of filmic effects overlayed on the cutscenes that distort and blur the shots as they are framed off, highlighting key moments and important plot points. The combination of these effects gives the production it's own unique feel.  Overall a must play of ANY action game enthusiast.

Max Payne 3 was Rockstar’s attempt at making a Max Payne game, as before it was Remedy who had done the previous two. Now right off the bat let me mention that fans of the previous 2 may or may not like the new Max Payne character as Rockstar seems to have changed him or at least the game’s tone from at times a 4th wall breaking humor to an ultra depressed middle aged man with a serious substance abuse problem. Max is still voiced by the same VO which is good because honestly I can only picture him doing Max’s voice. I can see where some of the criticism is coming from as far as the seemingly negative way Rockstar has changed Max’s character and tone towards life. However I can also appreciate the changes; Max is older, he has been dealing with the loss of so many of his loved ones that you can not deny what that could do to a person mentally. The still framed pictures or comic book type loading and cut-scenes have been replaced with fairly well done but good looking in-game cut-scenes, which some people hate because well if you die a lot then you have to rewatch every single one multiple times and sometimes it just seems to take the game forever to load that section of the level. Much of the cut-scenes have an odd video interference effect which some people complain causes headaches because it can cause the screen to flash different colors and tones rapidly. It was honestly an odd choice because it happens throughout the entire game, not just when Max is under the influence of drugs or alcohol.   The combat however, at least to my memory, I still have my old Max Payne 1 and 2 disks here, has not changed in fact to me it has been improved dramatically, some ways it is a step back but I’ll get to that. The animations, Max’s movements are very fluid and stunned me when I first saw them, Max no longer rigidly flys through the air and clips through walls and other objects, his body reacts differently to what he hits or slides along. The gunplay and shooting in very pleasing however it seems to be more geared towards being somewhat realistic as far as weapon damage. No longer can Max take hit after hit and a headshot from the enemy is an instant death, which is something very new to the series, at least as far as I can remember. The slow motion gunplay as well as gunplay outside of bullet time is quite enjoyable and a vast improvement over what it was in the past, movement and aiming is much more fluid and responsive. That being said one addition to the slow motion bullet time system that Max Payne has been known for is what amounts to a last stand, or rather if you are mortally wounded but still have painkillers in your inventory, the game will automatically pop the pills and you will fall in place while in slow motion in an attempt to kill the person who brought you own. Doing so will allow you to recover from what would have been a death, failing to find any target let alone return the fatal shot to the enemy who shot you will result in death. This plays into both this game’s improvement and a potential and constant problem; sometimes when you are put into last stand you quite literally can not see the person who shot you OR what normally happens is that Max falls in such a position that he can not actually get a shot at the target thus ending in a very frustrating death. This unfortunately happens rather consistently throughout the game so that is one major negative that I can readily ID and say “I am honestly not sure that they REALLY play tested that idea”.  The story and setting are fairly different from what most Max Payne vets are used to playing, rather then New Jersey or New York apartments, side streets and allyways, fighting mobsters. You are now fighting in Brazil against gangs, paramilitary organizations and state forces. The settings are quite well done as is the atmopher, gone are you abilities to readily understand the NPCs within the game unless they speak English or unless you speak I believe Portuguese (I could be very wrong sorry) which makes you feel very isolated and even more alone many times. The story can be either good or bad depending on how you look at it or what kind of story that you enjoy, some will like it, others will hate it, I happened to like it.  The music is another major factor to me if how I feel while playing, if a game has bad music while I’m trying to do action rolls and dodging the experience may not feel as good as a game that has a good sound track. This title however does have quite a good sound track and the music fits many of the situations that you run into especially the last level song, it really gets you pumped to finally see the end to this story, to me anyway, others have said it was too house or techno and not fitting of Max Payne. It will come to personal opinion honestly. The sound effects are really well done, from the weapons fire, the explosions and the ambient environments everything feels like a lot of effort was put into making it feel right. The past 2 Max Payne titles never really had any problems with this however I was happy that despite Remedy not making this game that Rockstar was able to keep that feeling.  The game also hits that little part of the brain for completionists, collectables for golden guns that actually have an in game benefit (mostly ammo capacity). So depending on what kind of person you are, you may end up playing through this game several times trying to get all of the little bits and pieces which can further extent your play time. It is however optional.  The multiplayer aspect is a different story as far as my enjoyment; while it is well fleshed out and not just some tacked on addition to meet the new generation requirement that every game needs multiplayer it is however not very fun. I did try to enjoy it, I even played with a friend but after maybe 4 or 6 hours of total time in the multiplayer I had had enough and to me the combat did not transition well from singleplayer to multiplayer. There are no dedicated servers so again PC gets a not so stable port for the multiplayer side of this game, it is Peer to Peer and in a game which revolves around slow motion and good aiming that is not a winning combination. Some people may enjoy it others do not, and on top all of this from what I understand there is a serious problem with cheaters and hackers.  Over all at least for the main story, not the multiplayer aspect of this game, I quite enjoyed the third iteration of Max Payne even if it was done by Rockstar. I enjoyed it and I felt that it was a worthy number to add to the franchise.

Max Payne. For any gamer who knows their salt, this name should be familiar. His publisher Take Two has released two games in 2001 and 2003 to great reviews and a decent amount of critical acclaim. Since then, though, the ex-cop has been left in the dust, barely being remembered other than that crappy movie that was released around then with Mark Wahlberg. It seemed for a while Max would just fade away, until back in 2012, when Rockstar Games, now owners of Take Two, released Max Payne 3. How was that? Well, we're taking a look at it now.  STORY: You're... Max Payne, of course. After the events of the last two games, Max is a drunken mess, he smokes regularly, he's addicted to painkillers, and he tries to find a reason to not blow his head off daily. Up until one day, when his old friend Passos comes across him and hires him to guard a wealthy family in Sao Paulo, Brazil named the Bronco's. Everything seems fine until the wife of the eldest Bronco is kidnapped, and Max and Passos go on a search to find her. That's all I can really say about it without spoilering it. It's a pretty well put together story. It can be pretty depressing at times when you see Max lose, but when he wins, which is kind of rare, it feels great. That's really all you can ask for. The story is a bit on the short side, took me 10 hours to beat it on Medium, but it's a good experience regardless.  GAMEPLAY: 3rd person shooter. You have 4 slots for guns. You have 2 slots one handed weapons, another for a two handed weapon, and the 4th one is dual wielding the two one handed weapons you have on you. All methods are satisfying enough, and gunplay is fantastic. The innovative Bullet Time from the last few games is here too, and that is great, and it has some new features. If you carry painkillers on you, and you lose all your health, you have a chance to shoot the guy who would have killed you and take him out, getting some health back and putting you back into the fight. Ammo can be a bit scarce, especially on the harder difficulties, but if you're efficient enough, you can do well. The game is freaking hard, btw, even when I played it on Medium, it was hard. The game is really satisfying when you beat the levels, and I ended up replaying it on Hardcore, which made me tear my hair out a bit but it was totally worth it. Gameplay is fantastic, maybe even best of 2012.  GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCE: Game looks good. The favelas of Sao Paulo look grimy and dirty, the nicer penthouses are well designed. There are a lot of nice details in all the levels without a doubt. This isn't a grand open world game like GTA or Red Dead Redemption or LA Noire like Rockstar is known for making, but the smaller levels are fine. They all look great. Game runs pretty well as well, since it's a game from 2012, if you have any recent hardware you should be fine. Runs well enough on my PC, and if I can run it, you can run it.  CHARACTERS AND VOICE ACTING: Max Payne has his voice actor from the last games, James McCaffery, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, is he as good as ever. The other characters are voiced well enough too. The characters look good, Max goes through a bit of a redesign halfway through which some people didn't like, but I thought he looked fine. Overall it's fine.  MULTIPLAYER: Practically abandoned on PC, played a bit on my 360, kind of fun, but nothing spectacular, odds are unless you get a big community for it you wont get to play it anyway.  EXTRAS: In each level, there are clues that relate to the story, though you have to look for a few of them. There are also some parts for golden versions of each weapon, and if you get all the parts scattered around the levels, you get a better version of the gun every time you pick it up. Once you beat the game, you unlock Score Attack, which is basically a kill and get points mode. There's also the New York Minute mode, where you have to beat a level in a minute. Well, you get time for killing guys, but still. If you arent impressed by that, then you have New Youk Minute Hardcore mode, in which you have to beat the whole game in a minute with the same bonuses, with no deaths. Yeah... good luck with that.  FINAL VERDICT: Phenominal game. One of the best of 2012, strong competator with Far Cry 3 and Mass Effect 3 for that slot. 9/10, it's worth picking up around a sale, hell, even right now. It's also one of the few games that I keep going back to time and time again to play through it once more, so I have to give some credit to them for that. Grab this game, you won't regret it

Oh, and don't forget needing to sign up for some obnoxious PC-only DRM service because Rockstar expects its paying customers to be treated like untrustworthy criminals! At least the PC version has some nice enhancements. Sure, they're only in the graphics department, and maybe in being able to actually customize controls assuming the console versions have that feature removed for no reason.  After this, you get to watch a long, unskippable cutscene that tells you 'game is still loading!' if you try to skip it... all before you're allowed to get to the main menu.  The menu of all things.  Want to watch it again, so you can see the story when you're not just trying to set up your controls and graphical settings? I hope you're technically inclined enough to find the .bnk file in the install directory, otherwise you can forget about that.  You're given a bland onslaught of in-your-face tutorials during the first chapter because clearly people who play games are too stupid to learn basic mechanics on their own, or in a separate tutorial- an option Remedy's titles offered. You're also given an introduction to the horrendous input lag this title has! Press a button to move, and Max pauses before doing so. Let go of the button, and Max keeps going for a second before deciding to stop. Try to shootdodge, and Max will pause before the effect actually begins. Everything feels delayed, even the simplest things like mouse movement. (I refuse to try using a controller to see if it's more responsive. I didn't buy a PC game to play with a controller. Outside of vehicle-related games, that's a bit like buying an HDTV to watch VHS cassettes on.)  Get used to seeing cutscenes, as there are a lot of them. Out of the playing time that's surely displayed with this review, I've probably gotten to spend under half of that in actual gameplay. I had bad flashbacks to Inversion while playing with the amount of '30 seconds of gameplay between multi-minute cutscenes' that was going on! Inversion at least had the benefit of not being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ization of an existing series of games. The rest is cutscene, cutscene, cutscene, with obnoxious and pointless effects plastered everywhere. Color desyncing, scanlines, freeze-frame of Max's face pushed to the side, the multiple-PiP effect of 24 fame, flashing lights, certain words that were  just spoken  needlessly printed to the screen... It's constant, erratic, and nauseating, especially when you're trying to actually  see what the hell is going on . Thanks Rockstar, I appreciate being given migraines when I try to play your games. There's also a strange anomaly regarding the cutscenes: each one phases between pre-rendered and real-time rendering for no particular reason. (This is most noticeable if you have recording software that reports framerate running, as the pre-rendered are thankfully very high quality despite the graphics clearly being below what the real-time graphics are capable of. Pre-rendered cutscenes 'run' at an incredibly higher framerate than the real-time cutscenes.)  Remember how I said the game punishes you for trying to play it as if it were a Max Payne game? Veterans of the series will see, in the rare gameplay segment, that trying to remain mobile and use bullet time and shootdodging will end up getting you killed as quickly as standing in an inferno. Instead, you're clearly expected to cling to cover like some Gears of War/Kill.Switch player and play it that way- including switching back to your main gun from your pistol because you're most likely in this situation straight out of a cutscene.  A few more horrendous gameplay changes are ones clearly decided upon because Rockstar wanted to make an Xbox game out of a historically PC-based series. Gone is Max's ability to hold an arsenal of weaponry and grenades that provide a variety of options for how to shoot up the next mook. Gone are even the names of the weapons! Max can now only hold two pistols, with the option to use either one of the two, or dual wield them (Ingram-style machine pistols count for this). You can pick up a two-handed weapon, but if it runs out of ammo or you want another two-handed, you have to drop the gun. If you get into a cutscene, you will have to switch back because you're forced to use a pistol again. Your weapon selection is a radial menu, clearly designed for a joystick. Painkillers now take effect near-instantly rather than healing over time, but it doesn't really matter since unless you're huddled behind cover like a generic modern TPS game your health's going to run low just as fast anyway. Run out of health, but have painkillers? Rockstar took a page from Call of Duty's book like so many other unoriginal people and give you a variation of 'last stand' - kill the person who 'killed' you and you get to stand back up. Fun! Challenging! Pointless!  Oh, and your ability to quicksave or save from the menu where  you  would like? Rockstar ignored that idea too. Can't give  too  much control to the player, right?  Overall, someone unfamiliar with the previous entries in the franchise and can stomach the awful input lag (or the thought of playing a PC game with a controller) might enjoy this, so long as constant cutscenes with nauseating effects aren't a problem. As a fan of the older games, and someone who just went through the entirety of Max Payne 2 again, I have to say this is the  true  Fall of Max Payne. My only consolation was I spent less than $5 on this thing during a sale, because I don't think I can be bothered to go any further.

Original post May 30 2012  gameaday-ish.blogspot.com   Max leapt and spun like a leaping and spinning thing, puking bullets in every direction, but unable to hit anything he aimed at. He grumbled to himself, dry and overly serious, deeply committed to the newfound film noir tone the original game had parodied. Max drank and took some painkillers, because that’s what haunted men do. They also shoot people.  A lot of people.  The simple joy of the original Max Payne lay in its mechanics rather than its all too self-aware neo-noir pastiche. While it did feature some truly haunting moments, the general tone of the game was a celebration of the inherent cheesiness of noir.   The fun lay in the ability to leap into a environment littered with enemies, pistols akimbo, and engage bullet-time, slowing the action to a crawl. Everything except Max would creep like molasses’s giving the keyboard and mouse wielding player razor sharp control.  Max Payne 2 updated the look but not the feel, replacing the blocky models with more polygons but retaining the bullet ballet aesthetic of the first game. With a slightly more complicated and less bizarre plot, Max Payne 2 is an underrated gem, though it does have it's own points of frustration. Like the horrific level in the first game of following a trail of blood towards an infant's screams in a nightmare, the second game has a brutal escort mission featuring a costumed character that waddles on flippers.  Max Payne 3 retains the bare bones of the mechanical joy of shooting, but, at least on console, lacks the precision necessary to make bullet time work. Combined with a corridor-based level design of cramped quarters and waist high walls, a cover mechanic is forced into the game, rendering the initial hook, bullet time, nearly useless. Only during what is essentially QTE sequences rendered in forced bullet time does the original mechanic sing.   I suspect PC will be the best control scheme for Max Payne 3 Where MP3 drops the ball carried by the first two games, it more than compensates in story.   Unlike the pyschodrama comic-book noir of the first two games, Max is a truly tortured soul in the third. Addicted to painkillers and a barely functional alcoholic, bad choices lead to Max working as a bodyguard in South America. Lost, both in spirit and body, Max struggles to make sense of the machinations and violence that surrounds him by shooting everyone he sees.  The final act outlasts its welcome, the emotional impact of the story already complete, leaving only a hollow revenge story to supply closure.  Max Payne 3 misses the mark in terms of replicating the bliss of slow motion shooting that inspires it but tells a gripping noire tale of a man descending into darkness.

After a long, nine-year-long sleep, Max returns with all the galantry and badassery we´ve come to expect, but this time he does so with some cool new additions which elevate this third entry above its two counterparts.   Some flashback sequences aside, the action has shifted from the cold, dark alleys of New York to the sun-soaked favelas of Brazil, a first in the series, and boy does it suit the franchise well. This setting is Rockstar´s perfect opportunity to boast some incredibly detailed scenarios and astounding lighting effects, not to mention Max´s life-like reactions and breathtaking cinematics.  The story, while engaging from the get-go, does get somewhat muddled by the end, with several different names flying by without giving you a second to give a face to them, but then again, the story has always shared this trait in the previous offerings. What never gets old are Max´s quirky remarks dotted throughout the 12-hour-long campaign, which have become a trademark of the cop´s adventures. The visual design works wonders with the narrative feel, as key words are highlighted when a cutscene hits, giving the title a distinct feel above other, more generic third person shooters.  Of course, what would Max Payne be without bullet time? Dead, that´s what. But fear not, because this aspect which made the first two games so appealing is back, now packed with more over-the-top situations in which to try it out. A cover sistem has been introduced for the first time, and it feels way more natural than just standing behind corners like a big ol´ chump the Max from nine years ago did. Also, this time you actually see your character taking painkillers, instead of just magically regenerating your health for no apparent reason. These cool new features, added to the increase in guns and varied level design, give the title at hand a new dose of realism, to the point you actually feel this guy could totally exist in the real world.  Last, and most probably least, is the multiplayer portion. While it carries over the amazing slo-mo kills and over-the-top action, it can´t help but feel tacked-on, a way to lengthen the game´s overall duration, but definitely not in a good way. It does provide a fun few hours, but that´s probably all you will spend in it.   Overall, Max Payne 3 is an amazing experience, proving Rockstar is not only the master of open-world games, but also really good at trying its hand at relentless, third-person action. It could use a bit of tweaking here and there, and the multiplayer portion could have been better implemented, but that shouldn´t distract you from what this game really is: a fantastic, dazzling, non-stop thriller which will grab hold of you and won´t let go until you see it through.  Pros:  + Intriguing, if somewhat muddled, story + Fantastic audiovisual design + Max´s character, a fascinating insight into one of gaming´s most beloved anti-heroes + Bullet-time and all the spectacle it provides + Social Club integration + Voice acting is once again top-notch  Cons:  - Lackluster multiplayer - Some of Max´s remarks don´t quite impress like they used to back in the day - A co-op mode would have been gratefully accepted  Final grade: 9.4 (Amazing)

Do I recommend Max Payne 3? Well, on one hand, it's an easy question; on the other hand, it's quite hard to answer it.  Fans of MP2 (like myself) will surely miss the grittyness and surreal, almost insane setting. MP3 is more down to earth, more in your face. The cutscenes in which Max breaks down are a little naiive and may appeal to younger players. Adults surely won't buy the over-the-top alcoholism and pill consumption displayed in the (partially non-skippable - why, oh, why?) sequences.  On the other hand, as the storyline unfolds, the game starts rolling, pulling you in. It's fast paced and action packed, which does a good job at making you forget about MP2. MP3 needs some time to get you into the mood, but once you start roaming the favelas, you get this good old depressive Max Payne feeling.  The controls definitely need some getting used to, but after you manage that, the game really starts paying back. A downside is that I almost never used the shootdodge technique, for which the Max Payne serier is so famous for. Too bad, it surely was a thing I was looking forward to. One thing that positively surprised me is its length. Aproximately seven to eight hours to complete the main storyline is quite ok these days. The learning curve is quite steep, so bear that in mind. It's by no means an easy game. There are also some graphical and sound bugs, which can be managed using the methods mentioned on the internets. I encountered only some sound problems which I got rid of by setting my speakers from 5.1 to 2.1. It surely didn't mess up the gaming experience.  So, do I recommend Max Payne 3? Yes, even though I definitely think it's inferior to Max Payne 2.

If you are a fan of Max Payne and Max Payne 2 by Remedy Entertainment, then I would suggest you replay one or both of those games instead of venturing into Max Payne 3 with its sloppy Rockstar Games version of the character and world. (This has nothing to do with the new setting or the presence of daylight in the game. It has more to do with a completely different approach to the character as well as storytelling in general. Think about getting a Twin Peaks movie written and directed by Michael Mann... it won't be the worst movie in the world, but it will inspire plenty of headaches.)  Even the mechanics of Max Payne 2 are superior to what you'll get in Max Payne 3. You will be relying on hiding behind cover and exploiting sloppy shooting mechanics throughout Max Payne 3. In a third person shooter, the player can put the crosshair on an enemy while the player's model is still behind a corner, resulting in bullets hitting a wall instead of the enemy in the crosshairs... or at least that's what happens in Max Payne 2. In Max Payne 3, if your crosshair is on an enemy and turns red, then the bullet will land... Max's actual position in 3D-space be damned...  That being said, it's not a terrible game. On its own, under a different/new IP, this would have been a good, maybe great, game. But they called it Max Payne 3, and as such it fails to hit the mark on many levels.

(Completed the game on Hard, only reviewing the single player)  Max Payne 3 has to be one of the games I have had the most mixed feelings about in a good while. The game does a lot right, delivering quality graphics and sound to match with a notably good soundtrack with decent voice acting. You really do feel like Max Payne himself, thrust into an alien and hostile environment as a naive gringo.  In my opinion the game fails mainly in terms of its... feel. It can feel tense and overwhelming at times as Max faces wave-upon-wave of enemies, with sometimes only as little as a baggage trolley for cover (not ideal when the enemy AI likes to flank Max). Yet you have the Max Payne series gimmicks of diving forward with bullet time, which can more often than not end up spending one of Max's pill bottles and gaining little compared to if he had just stayed behind cover. Is the game supposed to be fun? I'm not so sure and I'm not so sure games even have to be. But there is a real contradiction between the absurdity of a single American Rambo tearing down actual armies, the diving forward with bullet time; and Max's frailty. It's very easy to find yourself on the wrong side of a Retry screen if you play recklessly, yet intuitively this feels like the sort of game in which you should. Instead, often it is better to retreat and find good cover than it is to dive forward clutching not one, but two Uzis and letting rip.  This is not Max Payne 3's only failing. The story, to me, was completely unengaging. Which is especially problematic when Rockstar insisted upon making most cutscenes virtually unskippable. This would be fine if they were few and far between but I have never encountered so many cutscenes in a third-person shooter; so many situations where the player loses control, loses agency for Max to simply walk through a door, or for Max to simply crouch behind cover. The player can do this! These do not need to be cutscenes! This was definitely a deliberate choice by Rockstar and in my opinion, a terrible one.  Collectibles like Clues and Golden Guns were particularly annoying in my playthrough of Max Payne 3. Golden Guns are sometimes hidden in levels in various nooks and crannies for the player to find, but Max Payne talks to himself saying things like 'I had to move fast' - encouraging, perhaps unwittingly, the player to move on and leave the collectibles behind! The collectibles felt more like a hindrance than anything else.  Overall this game frustrated me as the potential was truly there. Varied locations; good graphics; good sound; strong animations. But the feel of the game turned into an arduous slog, weighed down by its self-important, overbearing story with its serious tone in an absurd situation.  Not recommended.

I don't really know where to start with this game.  I didn't play the multiplayer. Just the single player. Extensively.  What I liked:  I liked that it didn't limit your 'bullet time' (for people not familiar, the slow-mo matrix time slowdown where you can see bullets and dodge them) when you jumped. This turns the game from merely another third-person shooter to a crazy skillshot fest.  And you're gonna need to use that ability a lot, because on the higher difficulties there are lots of enemies, and you die quickly. They make it even harder by strapping armor to the enemies, forcing you to aim for weak spots like the neck and eyes.  It has a surprising amount of replayability. I found myself replaying single player levels over and over, not just for the collectibles (finding golden gun parts for weapons and other story bits) but just because it's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome to jump off of stuff and slow mo gun down hordes of brazillians and mobsters.  In terms of difficulty, it accomodates everyone. There are built in god mode and infinite ammo options, as well as the standard easy, medium, hard, realism (bullets do different damage based on where they hit, so a headshot on you is an instant kill) and 'old-school' (you die upon your damage meter filling up instead of going into a 'second wind' mode where you have to kill the guy who shot you to survive).  The story is interesting too. I liked the writing. It's nothing special, but I liked that it gave context to what happened and wasn't super crazy.  What I didn't like:  The filters. Jeez they hurt my eyes. It's way too bright.   I didn't like how on some levels there were invisible timers. Like I understand why they're there (without spoiling, people are kidnapped and you need to save them before they get away) but they really prevent you from exploring to find guns, pills (health), and collectibles.  Also the final levels aren't the best designed. They're basically open rooms with sparse cover, guys with LMGs and massive amounts of armor, and you. If you're godlike you can actually drop these guys by putting a bullet into this tiny, tiny, TINY spot where their visor is on their face or the thin slit of their neck, but otherwise, you're dropping easily over 20-30 rounds into each of them. And you better be good with that bullet time, because you're gonna need it when there's only two walls, enemies coming in from 3 directions, and you with only 2 berettas.  Also I felt that the weapon attachments could be expanded upon. Like sometimes your pistol comes equipped with a surpressor and/or a flashlight, but other than toggling the flashlight, there's not much you can do with it. And the surpressor is useless like 95% of the time anyways, and you only get them on certain missions.  Final Verdict:  It's a fun game. And it has tons of replayability. Get it on sale. 8.5/10

Only just behind it is the graphics which genuinly suprised me. The animations in paticular are very lifelike and the gunbattles all turn extremely cinimatic, as though every bullet is planned. Control is smooth and responsive, and the bullet-time effect is still very satifying. Rockstar are well aware that they were the creators of this now ubiquitous gameplay mechanic, and they still do it best.  Adding 'golden-gun' parts to each level encourages exploration; it was one of the games that after finishing, I went right back to playing it again, to see if I could find all the hidden items. It doesn't hurt that trying to get through each room more effeciently is part of the game's charm: there is nothing better than bursting through doors and laying waste to everyone without taking a scratch.   No real complaints; this was a sleeper of a game, I don't know why it didn't get more attention.

Seriously, play this game. It is one of the greatest experiences I have ever had in gaming. The story is quite good although feeling somewhat angsty at time, albeit that is not a bad thing in a game made by Rockstar. As for the visuals, they are outstanding to comment in the least. Lighting is spot on, character models for even the typical cannon-fodder enemy are incredibly detailed and don't even get me started on the weapon modeling. I could write a whole paragraph at how entertaining and intriguing it is to simply watch the show of firearms, well firing as shells fall smaking from chambers opening and recokcing repeatedly it's simply beautiful to watch a game truly nail gun operation visually. As a Max Payne title, you will be spending quite a bit of time shooting and it's quite a delight to know that the shooting is akin to the other aspects of the game, outstanding. Enemies use the euphoria procedural animatiion system which realistically models and renders physical impact (e.g enemy getting shot in the arm, his shoulder will flench) and the detail Rockstar put into the wounds and 'gore' is a little unsettling at how convincing it can be. There are several weapons to acquire which include the plethora you'd expect, assault rifles, submachine guns, handguns, and even a high caliber sniper rifle at one point in the game. I won't go into more detail about the gameplay and visuals as I mentioned, I could go on for days about how good it really feels and looks. That's basically all I can spout about the game without revealing too many plot details (which you will be in for some suprises!) Overall, Max Payne 3 is probably my favorite Rockstar with a close seconds being Red Dead Redemption and Max Payne 2. Typically the GTA series outshines Max Payne as Rockstar's signature series, but in almost every aspect (disregarding the world size) in Max Payne 3 is more enjoyable in my opinion. If you have a spare 20 dollars, you most likely won't be dissappointed in this game at all, as I pre ordered it when it came out. Now, the cons are: Story Mode is VERY linear, it has a LOT of long cutscenes and you will feel angry at some point after the game constantly interrupts the action to show cutscenes that sometimes didn't need to be there. The game is still quite long for a modern shooter and when you do get to shoot some stuff, it feels great so maybe you will be able to forgive that linearity. They put a lot of effort into this game and it shows, in terms of production values the game is nearly perfect. The graphics are very good even on low settings, but the game is optimized well enough to run smoothly on a year-old low/mid range laptop. Fans of the previous games made by Remedy may be disappointed, as 3 has some major stylistic differences. The graphic novel storytelling has been replaced by cinematic cutscenes which, while competently made, have a visual style that I personally found irritating, and the game is very cutscene-heavy. The film noir aesthetic is almost completely gone and the style is more reminiscent of something like Die Hard 4. The story is also heavier and more serious than the previous games and doesn't have any of the weird/quirky humor.  The gameplay is generally fine, though again, fans of the previous games might dislike the more modern design choices such as heavily cover-based shooting and limited amount of weapons you can carry. If you want to play this like the old Max Payne games, I recommend playing on Easy, as the game is quite challenging and the Medium difficulty already had some tough firefights that might become frustrating for the average player (they did for me, at least).   As you can probably tell, I came into this game as a fan of the series, and overall I was slightly disappointed with some of the stylistic choices Rockstar made, most notably the heavy reliance on cinematics. Still, Max Payne 3 is by no means a bad game, and it's easily worth the price, especially when it goes on sale (which it does frequently). I'd give it a 7/10, probably an 8/10 without fan bias.

Bought this game during the midweek madness sale for 7 bucks with all DLC. Gotta say, definitely worth the $.  The singleplayer campaign is about 8-10 hours long depending on if you take the time to go through and find the golden weapons parts. It's also one hell of a ride, with a plot twist that does a good job of hiding itself, but afterwards feels almost obvious. If it were any other game, this might've been a downside, but you get played as the depressed american ex-cop being dragged along for the ride without really knowing why or by whom to the point where it works. Max is also probably one of the most depressing characters I've ever seen, to the point where you half expect him to put a bullet in his skull at the end. (Spoiler Alert: He doesn't.) Again, this would be seen as a downside, but since this is pretty much the basis of the entire game and they pull it off so well, it works. The constant monologuing can become a little much, though it has its moments of charm when you pick up a random pill bottle or secret. All in all, I'd give the singleplayer an 8.5/10.   For a PC port, the controls were actually really solid. I usually play third person games with the 360 controller, but the kb/m controls worked well enough for me to stick with them. I could definitely tell that the game was made with a controller in mind. At the same time though, I didn't feel I was at any disadvantage for not using one. The gunplay is smooth and it's not hard to pick your targets. Bullet time is done well. You have a bar next to your ammo counter that refills as you move and take out enemies. A full bar will give you about 10-15 seconds of bullet time, which is plenty of time to pick off 4-5 guys in a room. If you take too much damage and have pills on you, you enter a bullet time sequence where if you take out the last guy to shoot you, you get a revive. This works most of the time, but often I would find myself holding my gun at an angle that I couldn't shoot the guy until the weapon was eventually at the magic angle to shoot him. Often, this would lead to me dying since I would run out of time to shoot him. I don't know if this is a bug or just an oversight but it happens enough for it to become fairly annoying. Overall though, I would have to give the gameplay an 8/10. The gunplay is great, the controls are tight for a PC port, and the bullet time is fun, but the bullet time revive is fairly glitchy and can lead to some annoyingly slow deaths.  Unfortunately, multiplayer seems to be pretty much dead. I played a few games, all of them being 1 on 1. It's a shame,too. The multiplayer isn't all that bad. The gameplay is fast paced and they even found a way to incorporate bullet time into it. I half expected it to be dead though. This isn't the game you spend months playing, but rather the game you pick up and play through on a weekend and then bury in your catalog for about 6 months. I'd give the Multiplayer a score, but I don't feel I've been able to experience enough of it to give it one.

Max Payne 3's got a different tone than the previous two Max Payne titles; some people didn't like the departure from the noir-esque setting. Some cover is destructable anyway, which pushes the player to always be on the move. The bullet-time/shootdodge mechanics are still all there and they feel as good as ever, and you'll probably end up relying on them more than the cover system anyway. The soundtrack compliments the feel of the game perfectly, the sound design is top-notch, and the level design is great too; it's pretty linear, but that's just the kind of game Max Payne's always been. And the set peices for intense firefights are layed out pretty much perfectly.  The only negative things that I can think of are the fact that multiplayer is pretty dead, and the story's departure from the tone of the original games. However, both of those things didn't matter too much to me, and gameplay-wise Max Payne is phenomenal. Pick it up if you're looking for a fresh old-school shooter.

Is it a good game? Yes. Is it a good Max Payne game? Sorta.  Sam Lake, who wrote the first two games, as far as I know did not work on this one. Rockstar worked hard at making the game's story sound and feel like the previous two, but there's no denying the typical Rockstar edges showing from behind the Max Payne screen. You'll occasionally get a very slight Grand Theft Auto vibe.   Let's face it, the narrative style of the first two games was heavy-handed, to say the least. It was written like a hard-boiled crime novel with a bit of supercop and a hefty dash of antihero, but as appropriately gritty and dark as the atmosphere was, it was obvious that every line in the story had been hard-pressed between two Thesauruses. Rockstar tried to emulate this style, knew its fans would expect it, and while it's considerably less archaic, it swings wayyyy too far in the opposite direction. The writing is sometimes forced, usually hit or miss, and the exposition is frequently unnecessary and downright boring. Rockstar's writing is about 'dark but funny', and it just doesn't quite fit. About halfway through the game, if not earlier, you'll simply be bored of Max's self pity.   I don't suppose I've ever thought about what would have happened to Max after the last story. His life destroyed, his revenge sated at the expense of the biggest fictional company Sam could muster and most of New York City's mafia. I suppose having him become a raging alcoholic and painkiller addict was only natural, but I didn't expect him to take on a job protecting a few rich ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in Brazil. The whole story seemed, I don't know, beneath him somehow. As though John McClane from the Diehard series went to the beach. Many times I asked 'Oh Max, what are you DOING in this place?'   The graphics are amazing. Point-blank amazing. As an added bonus, I think this game has the most realistic rag-doll physics I've ever seen. If you jump into a sideways dodge and there's a wall there - you smack against the wall and drop, not just slide off of it. Enemies respond to where they're shot, there are nice impact physics, cover is highly destructible, and the bulletcam closeups can be gruesome. My only complaint is MASSIVE overuse of some bizarre double-vision/highlighting/hue tint effect. I think it's supposed to represent Max's withdrawal (or possibly overindulgence on those painkillers), but it's excrutiatingly annoying and not a single cutscene goes by that doesn't bombard you with it.   It's a good thing the game is sheer joy for third-person shooter fans, because it's a corridor shooter. Sometimes enemies will corral themselves through a doorway for you while you pick them off. This wasn't overly common, and was the only time I felt enemies were stupid. The AI is pretty good, they'll work together to bring you down, change spots, and so forth. Moving with your gun drawn is a plus, though if you have any sense of tactical movement, you'll find yourself sometimes skipping the cover and simply picking enemies off with line of sight. Although you can pick off enemies with headshots, should they have body armor it can take a ridiculous amount of ammo to bring them down on just the medium setting. The problem is you can shoot AROUND the armor, but it doesn't seem to make a difference in damage calculations, which means it can take half a dozen rounds in the upper body even though you hit all flesh. Late game you feel as though you're gunning down intractable zombies rather than people.   I hope you didn't get overly attached to the old school style of hoarding guns in the previous two games, because you'll be dealing with Rockstar's selection wheel. You can only carry two single-handed guns (with a third slot to wield them together), and a single slot for the larger guns. The problem here is that in EVERY cutscene, Max switches back to a single handed weapon, which means when you get back to the action (and probably have people to shoot), you have to hit 4 to re-select your bigger gun. This is intrusive, takes a second, and although the game is pretty good about starting you out behind cover, was something easily fixable. In spite of these limitations, you'd have to be pretty bad to run out of ammo. The game is also fond of randomly taking all your ♥♥♥♥ away during cutscenes, even if there was no particular reason why you should have lost the extra weapons.   WHEN you go down in combat, you're given the opportunity to shoot your attacker in bullet-time, which will auto-consume one painkiller and leave you on the ground. While this conceivably prevents many game overs, Max is pretty clunky in that he has to get up all the way and THEN re-assume cover, eating bullets in the process. Painkillers are more common, and should you die, you won't lose them at the checkpoint. You do, however, lose all your bullet-time in a 'last man standing' bit, however unlike the previous games, bullet time doesn't necessarily require kills to regenerate.   One minor complaint I have is grenades. You don't get any. Ever. Your enemies sometimes do, but while this mechanic was hardly ever abused, it was certainly noticeable.   The checkpoint system is better this time around. It's not perfect, and there are some longer stretches that will have you uttering whole streams of curse words when you die.   The whole game is very cinematic, which is good because it's short. All-told, the campaign is roughly 9 hours long. I definitely recommend it for third-person shooter fans.

MP3 is no longer the dark detective noir story of MP1 and 2. Instead, it takes Max Payne as a character and dumps him in a gritty and realistic world, set in Brazil. Personally, I found this a good move; Max's character is given a lot of room to breath, and the dialogue and monologue help to characterize him in fantastic ways.  Gameplay-wise, MP3 is still incredibly difficult, but much more forgiving; multiple failures will restart you at a checkpoint with more painkillers and ammo. Bullet-time is still a thrill to run around in.  And probably one of the more impressive aspects of MP3 is the animation. Max twists his body around to maintain his aim, enemies fall down realistically, and Max won't magically slide down walls as he's jumping to the side; he'll smash into them. Realistically!  If you're not tired of Max doling out 'Max Paynisms' as well as bullet, MP3 is definitely worth the buy.

Ok, I will begin by saying that I had massive expectations for this game. It being a Rockstar game and I being a massive Rockstar fan. Honestly, it kinda disappointed me. Let me tell you why. It's a fairly bad console port. Out of all the things that impressed me positively or negatively, that's the biggest one. It reeks of console-specific 'features', that, of course, are useless and annoying on PC, and every self-respecting PC gamer should be able to identify and condemn these specific 'features'. First of all, is the aiming. It's bad. It doesn't allow you to finely control the sensitivity, the sensitivity is controlled in big chunks, so it's either too fast or too slow. Even if you put both horizontal and vertical sensitivity on the SAME value, it's still different, and you can't get them to match perfectly, because, I said previously, the horizontal-vertical sensitivity difference is fairly small, and the values to which you can adjust the sensitivity are big. So it will never match. It's annoying. Then it's the movement and sprinting. Sprinting is done Gears of War style, when you press shift you basically become a tank. Super-slowly moving either left or right while you race ahead. Not the best way to do sprinting. Movement is very wonky. It's one of those cases where Rockstar tried to make the movement more reallistic than it's fun to play. And that's not fun to play. Max stutters a lot when he encounters an object, and switching quickly from moving left to right is a nightmare, it takes AGES! Not very good when you're in a tight situation. I crouch a lot behind cover, a habit from the old days, when you didn't stick like glue to walls to the press of a button. Crouching is also a nightmare, it takes 2 seconds for Max to switch stances, and that's only when the button decides to work. If you press it too quickly, the system goes crazy and Max freezes in place like a massive idiot, becoming a glorified bullet sponge. But what are you going to do, it's easier for console scrubs to press a button and become glued to the wall, than to actually manage moving while crouched... Between all of these control and aiming issues, the game became quite challenging even on Easy... I'm used to more responsive games, coming from a background of mainly Counter-Strike, where the aiming and movement is supposed to work perfectly, like clockwork. And more and more modern games suffer from this issues, because they don't spend enough time to polish the PC port, so that it becomes decent. Like I said, I was a little disappointed by this game, I didn't expect to have so many issues with a Rockstar game. The story is a good Max Payne-like story, I enjoyed it until the end, and it's really worth playing. The multiplayer on the other hand is very disappointing. Especially now, 3 years down the line. Again, this being a Rockstar game, and quite a good one as well, I expected more people to play it. But it's a wasteland down there. The only mode still being played, although you have to wait a few good minutes to get any players at all, is Team Deathmatch, the most popular gamemode in all of online gaming... The others are barren as a desert. No one playing them. I had to get a friend to buy the game, just to try the coop horde mode it had, since no one was connecting to my lobby. And when you finally do get matched with someone, it will mostly be with very high level players, which all of them have better guns, better perks, better everything, so you don't stand a chance. Again, probably because of the very low player count, it had to match me, a level TWO (2) against a team of level FIFTY (50) or close to that, otherwise none of us would be playing any multiplayer any time soon. All in all, I would recommend the game for singleplayer, it's a good story, about 8 hours long, the rest I spent in multiplayer, and if you're not a very picky gamer, like I am, you could get easily used to the control issues the game has, but don't have any expectations from the multiplayer aspect of the game. I bought it at a sale, I recommend you wait for one as well.

Oh man this game.... this gem, the Max Payne series were the first games that I've played on PC ever. Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is for me, the epitome of a great noir-crime game.  When I heard that there was a Max Payne 3, which was completely unbeknownst to me, I IMMEDIATELY bought it. And did it deliver...?  Yes, it did. Max Payne 3 looks very different from its predecessors. The rundown, bleached buildings and shadowy sidewalks of New York have been replaced by the hedonistic nightclubs and baking heat of São Paulo, where Max has taken a job working private security for wealthy businessman Rodrigo Branco. Unsurprisingly, things don’t work out for Max: Rodrigo’s trophy wife, Fabiana, is kidnapped on Max’s watch, which sets in motion a chain of events that draws Max into a much larger, more sinister story that just left me in shambles.  Story: 10/10 It touches on the disparity between rich and poor, and how resentment and desperation can fester in the slums and the penthouses alike. This isn’t only tackled in the main story, but also in nice scraps of incidental narrative recovered in clues dotted about the meticulously-crafted environments. The single-player story lasts around 10-12 hours.   Graphics 8.5/10: Not the best looking game around but environments are impressively detailed and performances sensitively captured.  Cinematics: 8/10  The action set-pieces seem a little muted, especially when compared to, say, the spectacular recent capers of Nathan Drake. But this isn’t necessarily a bad thing.  Sound: 9.5/10 Stirring and evocative soundtrack by the LA rock band ''Health''. Bound to get you pumped.  Final Verdict: 9.5/10 New gameplay elements like the cover-system are implemented very good, but the lack of innovation makes the action a bit tedious towards the end. Nonetheless Rockstar delivers a good game and even more important: it deserves the name Max Payne.  There are plenty of games which are critically acclaimed for their gameplay but lack anything in way of story or character. Max Payne 3 is a different type of proposition. The gameplay is simple yet.. satisfying, but it’s entirely in the service of a strongly-authored narrative. Players aren’t at the liberty to roam, to explore, or to shake things up. Some might find this too controlling, but in return for your freedom, you’re rewarded with a mature genre piece which is also a finely-realised character study.
